body.p:
In reply to yours of the 19th instant, I find the explanation
you have given of the observations which appeared in the Sepr. number of
the Occident totally unsatisfactory you say:

“In regard to your inquiry about the ? of the Asmonean, I have to
tell you frankly that if it is true that you charged the people at
Albany ten dollars for inserting a reply to Mr Spanier and then
refuse doing it nevertheless, it does not look well, and this
is what they asked me to print, together with some reflections
which I thought it not to my business to make public. My
correspondent writes " The Asmonean was directed to insert it and
answered in a letter in our possession now to give it insertion as
an Editorial for ten dollars. But one day after this the Asmonean
came out with an abusive language and its wise editorial remarks.”

Now for the life of me, I cannot discern form this statement
whether the people at Albany say, or you believe, that I charged
them ten dollars under pretence of giving insertion to what you
now call a reply to Mr Spanier and that I afterwards refused to
print it notwithstanding they had so paid for it. Inexplicable
as is your letter to me, your statement in the Occident assumed
the truth, without your having troubled yourself to test your
correspondents veracity. However let us look at the facts.

After having refused to notice the Albany quarrel or to side
with either party, the Asmonean of July the 19th published the

card from Mr. Spanier, but an early post I was favored with a letter
enclosing what purported to be a report of a meeting whereat the
members of the congregation Beth El were present who passed certain
resolutions therein set forth; the letter requested that I would publish
the enclosed report. I replied in two ways firstly by letter probably to one
or two persons referred to, and secondly, in the columns of the Asmonean of
the 26th of July. My letter to Mr Beckel stated, “I must decline giving
insertion to the report in its present form. Justly I have refused'
insertion to communications containing personalities against Dr Wise
hence I must reject attacks upon the other side Secondly, the whole
of the ? resolutions are couched in language unfit for publication
and totally inadmissible into the columns of the Asmonean “x x
xxxxxxxxxxxxx' The seventh to the twelfth resolution
with a slight revision of the language would be inserted.”

“Should you see fit to withdraw the objectionable matter and substitute
that now suggested” “the charge for its insertion in the editorial
columns of the Asmonean will be 12 cents p line and as it
will num to eighty lines the price would be ten dollars which you will
please to remit when you forward your instructions ? the same”

It must be understood that the first six resolutions those to which
I imperatively refused insertion were a libellous attack upon Mr Spanier.
The next resolutions laudatory of Dr. Wise and of exposing the meetings
confidence in him as a Preacher &c I offered to insert upon slightly ?
the language (making it english). And I ? the entire report as a
personal matter, issued for party ends and personal gratification; hence
it was an advertisement and to be paid for as such.

From having been assailed in the pages of the Occident. I desire
that the same channel should be used to remove the expression aspersion,
therefore, I furnish you, as its Editor, with the above Extract from my letter
book requesting that you will in the next number, give place in your
own name, to a lucid and satisfactory explanation, for you must
readily perceive, and acknowledge, how indiscreet was the statement,
and arrogant the assumption expressed by you, when you stated
“that the publication of the ? of the Editor of the Asmonean would
injure him, and increase your circulation.”

I shall not deign to comment on the evident bad taste which
induced you, a professor of Divinity, to pen the following “a charge which
we do not care just now to bring down upon us” the words undeserved
by me, may possibly have reference to your present hostile position
with your congregation, or may prospectively regard the forthcoming “Jewish
Advocate” but ere the Editor of the Occident wrote just now he
should have recollected, that I, as the Editor of the Asmonean, did
through its agent at Philadelphia Mr Michael Allen, place its columns
at the service of the Rev Isaac Leeser to answer and refute the charges
of his opponents. And further that I am in possession of two notes
wherein Mr Leeser writes “that he is greatly obliged to the Editor
of the Asmonean for his dignified notice of A Review; and in the
second Mr Leeser requests a notice, and remarks “that he is not
ungrateful for favors conferred”

It matters little to me, how you act with respect to notices or
reports; the Asmonean while under my charge will be conducted as
I deem fit, but if you refer to an editorial of mine published

July the fifth you will perceive that I publicly announced that matters
of public import or general interest would be inserted gratis, but that
matter for private ends would be subject to charge. However if I do
see fit sometimes to depart form this rule of the profession, the Albany
affair was not one to induce me. But this week I shall do so, and
shall publish gratuitously a series of resolutions laudatory of yourself
and concerning the Occident. And I do this with the feelings
that invariably actuate me—to wit—a perfect contempt for personal
?, and a desire to forward everything having a tendency
to elevate the intellect and humanise the affections of my
fellow men.

As I am particularly desirous that this matter should
be entirely cleared up before your next issue of the Occident
I must press upon you for an early reply stating the course
you purport taking
